content:
I've made the changes below after receiving feedback on the forum ( https://forum.codingame.com/t/community-puzzle-xml-mdf-2016/203108/9 ).

Goal
* I've added the word "English".

* I've formatted "-", the example strings and tags as {{constants}}.

Input / Constraints
* I've added the variable name "[[sequence]]".

* I've moved the maximum length of [[sequence]] from Input section to Constraints section, and changed it from 1024 to 300, which is closer to the length of the longest input strings among the cases.
If Iâ€™m not wrong, the "example" should be "ab-bcd-d-c-ae-e", and not "ab-bcd-dc-ae-e".

I agree with AzureLithium. The "Several deeper..." test was invalid. I have fixed this problem, and I also took the liberty of slightly modifying the two tests that I had complained about previously. Now all Tests are unique from the Validators. Given these changes, I have voted to approve this puzzle. Nicely done.

Test and validator:

"Several deeper nested might win too"

are wrong. They shouldn't have their first hyphen.

Besides from that, nice problem NikoNikoSuru.
I made some minor edits to the Statement to correct for typos and grammar.

And I have verified all tests and validators, but I want to point out that the validators are simply an exact copy of the corresponding tests. This is not recommended practice, and should be changed. It is very easy to come up with comparable, but different, validators for this particular puzzle.

If you make this change and let me know, then I will add my approval to the puzzle.
Good catch. I have fixed the problem.

Okay. It's better, but "Several deeper nested might win too" and "Size should not matter" are still identical between test and validator. Would you be willing to just slightly modify these validators to make them unique? It's probably just the OCD in me, but I'd appreciate it.
